addressleaf.section:
D
r
Birch's Memoirs Vol.5 Page 217.

page.lettertext:
fol.110r
May it please yo
r
good L. Among dyvers l
re
s sent from
Brus-
sels
, and intercepted heere of late, I sent you two, w
t
my last
of
e 26 Feb
r
and heerew
t
a third, which was alsoe written
by
e same
Crytton
to
James Tyrius
e Scottish Jesuit at
Rome,
and did not seeme to be regarded by those
at kept
e l
re
s.
But I fynde it worth
e reading for many respectes, because
it doth manifest
at there are many brabbles, and disconten-
tments among those of
at nation in Brussels and else where:
and
at they are in despaire of good successe in
e enemies
actions both heere and in
France.
It is also easie to per-
ceave by perusing
e wordes interlaced with
e figures,
at
there is mater there signified of speciall importance;
which if it canot be deciphred by any at home, I am of
opinion
at
e Copie of
e l
re
being sent to some man
at
is of Capacitie, and imploied by your L. in Brussels or
Andwerp,
if he be but acquainted, w
t
e Scottes
at are
there, and
e factious among them, it will be p
nt
ly disco-
vered. These
at are heere of
e Scottish nation for
want of knowledge, who they are,
at are there, and how they
stand for affection one to an other, can give me no light.
As touching my negotiation,
e returne of
e Deputies of
Gueldres
and
Overissel,
are dayly now expected, and then
e
States,
I am certaine, will delyver me their answear, without
putting me of to a further delay. We have assured in-
telligence from dyvers places of
e Enemies contreis,
at
e vul-
gar people every where, crie openly out against their miseries,
shewing manifest token
at they desire to be joyned to the
rest of this union. And as farre as I can judge of
e
States inclination, if
e motion proceede from
e other
side to them, thereafter as it is they are fully bent to inter-
taine it, to
e best advantage of their cause. But whe-
ther it were expedient,
at we should stryke at this yron,
whyle it is hotte, and be the first
at should send to
e Enemies
Provinces,
at doth rest in deliberation: albeyt I doe per-
ceave
at most men are of minde,
at we should not sturre
in this case, but as occasions are presented from them
unto us. For this alleaged for it, That before they
send to
e Enemie, in a mater of
at importance, they
fol.110v
must first of force heere at home have recourse to every Pro-
vince, to purchase autoritie, wherby it will be imparted to
every towne, and soe come abroade among
e people, who as
every man doubtes, may prove soe over headlong in suche
a plausible motion, as perhaps when they see it is once
sette a foote, they will violently thorowe, without regarde
to their owne securitie. The feare of this humor in
e
multitude, doth stay them from proceeding as they are
otherwyse willing. It is co
m
only reported
at
e Enemie prepareth for
e siege of
Huy,
w
ch
he will fynde
a very hotte and a costly exploit. For
Haurangieres
the
co
m
aunder is a valiant expert souldier, and will undoubted-
ly perfourm as muche as can be required.
And
thus I take my humble leave. Ma
r
4 1594.
